intro: Bupleurum ranunculoides f. canalense, commonly known as the Canary Islands buttercup, is a rare and endemic plant species native to the Canary Islands. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its umbellate inflorescences and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows in rocky or limestone soils, thriving in the unique microclimates of its native habitat. Its flowers are usually white or pale yellow, with five petals and a distinctive central disc. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species, highlighting the importance of conservation efforts in its native region.
